### Prerequisites

The interpretation of texts and historical events is grounded in the continuity of ideas. Considering this scenario, we suggest, as a first step, studying the text about writing systems

### Introduction

The study of a text goes beyond simply memorizing fragments. It involves a detailed identification of the context in which it was written, including the historical period, the location, the authors' ideas, and the environment in which they lived. In other words, there are multiple elements to analyze. Given this complexity, we begin with a reflection

text:
Reflection 1: The Nature of Texts

When studying the space and time in which a text was created, we work with concepts from Physics and Geography. Investigating the surrounding environment and the tools used, we incorporate knowledge from Chemistry and Biology—disciplines directly connected to the living beings who produced the text.

Considering that texts are intrinsically linked to the natural sciences, how would you explain the perceived artificial separation between Mathematics, known as the language of nature, and Literature, as understood by some people?

text.text: ### Unifying When discussing the writing systems of the six cradles of civilization, we highlighted the unique characteristics of each. However, we were able to unify them into a single text thanks to the following definition from the Britannica Encyclopedia

text: • Languages are systems of symbols; writing is a system for symbolizing these symbols. A writing system may be defined as any conventional system of marks or signs that represents the utterances of a language

text.text: This definition allow us to include all writing systems in an unique group, that we will identify as W

text: Chart 1: Representation of the unified writing systems of humanity.

text.text: ### Without a Writing System The group W, which unifies all writing systems, indirectly also defines the existence of another group: group I, composed of images and symbols that do not represent a writing system

text: Chart 2: Representation of images that are not considered writing systems..

Biology in Literature

When we isolate images created by humans that do not constitute a writing system, or when we state that a group of people did not develop a civilization, we are not diminishing these people. They remain Homo sapiens, sharing the same origin as all humans approximately 250,000 years ago (Wang, Richard J., et al. ; Templeton A. R., ; Templeton A. R., ).

text.text: An example of images that are not part of a writing system is cave art, created between 40000 and 14000 years ago. An example of such art can be found in the Altamira Cave in Spain

text.text:
### Ungrouping

The process of separating writing systems to study them based on shared characteristics does not imply that they are reduced to cave art. This division aims to create subgroups within a larger group, organizing them by more specific traits while preserving the essential characteristics that justify their unification

source.text: Rowland, Todd and Weisstein, Eric W.

text.text: With this framework, we can classify the writing systems widely recognized by academia into two categories: cuneiform (Group C) and hieroglyphs (Group J). It is important to note that knots (quipus) are not yet included, as further study is required to classify them accurately

text: Chart 3: Representation of writing systems in subgroups.

### Conclusion

In this text, we continued the previous discussion by introducing an essential concept for text interpretation: groups. We began by highlighting how the structure of the first text could be constructed as it is, thanks to the definition of writing systems provided earlier.

Next, we explored how the concept of writing systems can be extended to encompass other groups
